Description: A pottery flask in the form of a figure (possibly an African slave) sleeping in a crouched position, resting against and holding his master's bath equipment, including a large ribbed-handled askos for hot water and, in his right hand, a strigil, beside which hangs a pointed-based amphoriscoid aryballos for bath-oil. His left hand rests on his stomach. Between his shoulders a ring-handle, now broken, was placed. The mouth of the flask rose from the top of his head, but is mostly lost. The back and the flat resting-surface of the flask are plain. Two-piece mould. Micaceous dark-grey Nile silt; thin black slip: Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Ptolemaic, second century BC. Comparanda: Close: Hilton Price 1897: 401, no. 3321, from Bubastis; Kotitsa 1998: pl. 68:118, from the Fayum, dated second half of second century BC = Hausmann 1962: 268-9, Beilage 77:3; Perdrizet 1921: no. 375, from Memphis; uclia, Gayer Anderson Bequest, ucl 1585. For the askos, compare a bronze example shown on the emblema of a mosaic of the early second century BC from a house at Chatby in Alexandria: Grimm 1997: 461, fig. 7a, and in Walker and Higgs 2001: 88, no. 95, dated c.200-150 BC. Also several miniature terracotta examples in Edgar 1911: pl. xxi.
